item.title: 6 Final Fantasy Villains With The Most Logical Motives
item.description:
Highlights

  • Final Fantasy villains vary in complexity, with some driven by power, protection, and revenge, not just malice.
  • Rufus Shinra, Vayne Solidor, and Ardyn Izunia stand out as villains with nuanced motivations beyond typical evil intentions.
  • Venat and Caius Ballad also showcase interesting motives, adding depth to their roles as antagonists in the Final Fantasy series.

Final Fantasy is a storied RPG franchise , with its various entries being incredibly influential to both the genre and gaming in general. Its villains are only one aspect of its incredible legacy, being fantastic foils to the various main characters and their journeys.

Related
Most Iconic Final Fantasy Characters, Ranked

The Final Fantasy franchise is responsible not just for some of the most iconic characters in RPGs, but the most iconic characters in all of gaming.

While many Final Fantasy villains have truly become iconic, their motivations are sometimes very basic, wanting only to cause death, destruction, and suffering wherever they go. However, some villains are slightly more reasonable, with more complex motivations than just malice and hatred. Here are some Final Fantasy villains that have some logic to their motivations.

6 Rufus Shinra (Final Fantasy 7)

The Ruthless President Of Shinra

Rufus Shinra is the vice-president of Shinra Electric Power Company, later assuming his father's position as president after his death . Calm, collected, and scheming, Rufus is a power-hungry executive who manipulates others to achieve his own ends. Though Rufus and the Shinra Company slowly lose prominence as major antagonists as Sephiroth and his actions take center stage, he and his men remain active opponents against Cloud and AVALANCHE.

Related
Final Fantasy: The Best Worlds To Live In

If players were to live in a world straight out of the Final Fantasy franchise, it would have to be one of the following.

Rufus plans to use Shinra's incredible power and influence in an attempt to control the populace, using fear effectively to keep them in check. Despite this power-hungry and tyrannical nature of his, Rufus does have a conscience, and while he prioritizes the image and status of Shinra, he will move to protect the populace when necessary, such as when Meteorfall occurs.

5 Vayne Carudas Solidor (Final Fantasy 12)

The Tyrannical Ruler Seeking Absolute Power

Vayne Carudas Solidor is the son of Archadia's Emperor and an ambitious man who yearns for power. His desire for power leads him to begin manipulating events, using Venat and the power provided by it to do so. Vayne is responsible for many of the injustices and cruelties suffered by the main characters, and a worthy target for their vengeance.

Despite his tyrannical nature and manipulative scheming, Vayne is not wholly evil, nor is his hunger for power out of selfishness. He has a genuine desire to protect the Archadian Empire and his desire for power comes from that.

4 Ardyn Izunia (Final Fantasy 15)

A Former Hero Turned Twisted Tormentor

Ardyn Izunia is a mysterious man who is slowly revealed to not just be an important figure in the Niflheim empire, but also the main antagonist of the entire series. Initially coming off as an odd and eccentric man, Ardyn soon reveals himself to be manipulative, sadistic, and cruel. Ardyn frequently encounters Noctis and his allies throughout the series, helping them at some times and hurting them at others.

Related
Best Handheld Final Fantasy Games, Ranked

Square Enix's iconic franchise also saw releases on handheld consoles. These are the most memorable entries.

However, Ardyn is not without his sympathetic side. He was once a kind and benevolent man who had the power to take on the pain of others. He was betrayed by both family and the Crystal , and slowly grew consumed by his rage, eventually giving in to revenge. Though his actions for the sake of vengeance were certainly villainous, it's hard to deny the anger and pain he felt.

3 Venat (Final Fantasy 12)

Attempted Liberator Of Humanity's Destiny

Venat is a member of the Occuria, a race of otherworldly immortal beings that watch over the world of Ivalice. The Occuria attempt to manipulate the fate of Ivalice from the shadows, granting great power to those who agree to do their bidding.

In opposition, Venat wishes to free humanity from the will of the Occuria, giving power to Vayne Solidor and the Archadian Empire to do so. While this motivation can be seen as benevolent, its actions end up aligning with the party's enemy, turning Venat into an opponent whose defeat is necessary.

2 Caius Ballad (Final Fantasy 13-2)

The World Destroyer With A Sensitive Soul

Caius Ballad was once the l'Cie guardian of the sorceress Yuel, tasked with protecting her and her ability to see the future, despite that ability ultimately killing her in the end. Forced to reincarnate over and over, Yuel lives endless lives, with her ability of foresight following her into every new life. Caius was given the gift of immortality to watch over these endless reincarnations, which would soon become a curse for him.

Tormented by having to watch Yuel's endless deaths and rebirths , Caius decides to kill Etro to free Yuel from her cycle of reincarnation. Though such an action would certainly have massive ramifications on the world as it is, Caius nevertheless persists in order to save Yuel from her endless fate.

1 Delita Heiral (Final Fantasy Tactics)

The False Hero Of The War Of The Lions

Delita Heiral was a commoner who became a knight, and childhood friend of Ramza Beoulve. Once idealistic, tragedy after tragedy turned Delita into a pragmatic and manipulative man who would do anything to achieve his goals. His change in attitude ultimately leads him to part ways with Ramza, as he now seeks to rule over the kingdom so that he can bring an end to the chaos.

Using manipulation and betrayal as his tools , Delita slowly works himself into a prominent role in the land of Ivalice, eventually marrying Princess Ovelia and becoming King. While he never directly engages Ramza in battle, his actions and motivations ultimately put him at odds with his former friend.

More
Final Fantasy: Forgotten Villains

These Final Fantasy villains, for one reason or another, aren't quite as memorable as the likes of Sephiroth, Seymour, or Kefka.

item.title: The Last of Us 3’s Theme Will Tell Players More About The Story Than Any Trailer
item.description:
A third chapter in the The Last of Us franchise is on its way. Series producer Neil Druckmann announced that he has completed a rough outline of the third game's story, and that he has a general idea of what its central theme could be. It will probably be quite a while until The Last of Us 3 rears its head, but this "central theme" will reveal more about its nature than any piece of promotional content. Players can likely expect The Last of Us 3 to make radical changes to the narrative and gameplay foundations of the game that preceded it, just like The Last of Us 2 departed from The Last of Us with major story and mechanical decisions.

Spoilers ahead for The Last of Us 2 .

The narrative premise of The Last of Us Part 2 was obfuscated in the lead-up to the game's release, with trailers intentionally misleading players into thinking that Joel was still alive. There were heavy suggestions that the story would center on revenge, but the particulars of its plot could only be speculated about. Most players (barring those who saw the leaks ahead of the game launch) couldn't have predicted that the person Ellie would be avenging was Joel. All this is to say that, whenever trailers for TLOU3 begin to drop, they probably won't be very illuminating.

Related
One The Last of Us 2 Relationship Could Be Even More Important in TLoU 3's Story

The Last of Us franchise has brought some complex relationships to life, and one in particular could get a bigger spotlight in Part 3.

The Importance of The Last of Us 3's Central Theme

Thematic Framing In The Last of Us

When discussing a potential third The Last of Us entry , Druckmann explained that the first two games were written with "clean" thematic cores in mind. He went on to say that the notion of unconditional parental love is at the heart of the first game's narrative, while Part 2 's story is meant to explore the concept of justice. Crucially, Druckmann has noted that the broad and nebulous idea of love is the throughline for the entire series.

Regardless of one's opinion about The Last of Us and its controversial sequel, it's undeniable that their narratives adhere to the aforementioned themes. The first game is clearly about parental love, as Joel loses his daughter and finds a surrogate daughter in Ellie, and Part 2 analyzes justice through the opposing perspectives of both Ellie and Abby. The franchise is clearly concerned with these sorts of lofty ideas, which inform the structure and content of the narrative. With The Last of Us 3 likely closing out the franchise , the importance of its theme can't be overstated.

The Theme of The Last of Us 3 Will Be the Best Indicator of the Game's Story

If the dominant theme of The Last of Us 3 gets revealed ahead of its release, either through interviews, promotional materials, or even another leak, it will probably be the biggest hint about the game's story. As previously stated, it wouldn't be advisable to put too much faith in any official trailers for the game, as Naughty Dog has proven that it can be deceptive in service of keeping spoilers under wraps. If The Last of Us 3 features another dark twist that sits at the heart of the narrative, akin to Joel's murder in Part 2 , it's conceivable that Naughty Dog would show only heavily edited or vague trailers. The studio would be especially motivated to do this after The Last of Us Part 2 's leaks, which undermined a lot of the game's initial fanfare.

Vague trailers also boost word-of-mouth promotion, as they prompt discussion and speculation online.

The Last of Us 3 may be more hopeful than previous games, and a clean, straightforward theme like acceptance could suggest the general direction of the game's story. Of course, this is just speculation, and no discussion about the theme will yield a play-by-play prediction of the narrative. But if someone is looking for a hint as to where The Last of Us 3 's story is headed, the core theme gestured at by Druckmann would be the best place to start.

item.title: 10 Great Video Game Arcs That Never Got An Ending
item.description:
Highlights

  • Budgetary constraints can lead to dropped plotlines in video games, leaving players disappointed with unfinished stories.
  • Many modern AAA games introduce multiple storylines and numerous plotlines, making it hard to keep track of everything.
  • Sometimes, important and engaging character arcs in video games are abandoned or forgotten in future installments.

Many people expect modern video games to have amazing and memorable narratives that are a joy to uncover. After all, gaming has evolved from its early days of having simple gameplay loops without any clear objective in mind. Many modern AAA games are so determined to allow players to do everything in their video games that simply having a main story isn't enough. Players also want side stories and complex character arcs to complement the experience as well.

Related
Best AI Characters in Video Games, Ranked

AIs have been NPCs, companions, antagonists, and such in video games for eons. These characters stand out as the most memorable AI in gaming history.

Given how complex video game development is, it's always possible that certain story arcs that are set up in video games never really reach any sort of a natural conclusion, being discarded in favor of other plot developments instead. The most notable instances of this are mentioned below.

Updated on May 28, 2024 by Ritwik Mitra: Video games have evolved from simplistic gameplay loops to featuring massive worlds, amazing stories, numerous plotlines, and everything in between. In fact, some games have so many storylines that it can be hard to keep track of them for both players and developers alike. This leads to some plotlines that are built up to be as major as can be, only for later events or titles to completely drop any mention of these stories. This can range from understandable to disappointing and everything in between.

10 Tanimura's Character Arc Dropped After One Game

Getting A Well-Established Actor's Likeness In Future Games Was Too Expensive

Yakuza 4 was the first game in the series to introduce multiple protagonists, making the narrative more engaging than ever before. One of the characters introduced in the story is an up-and-coming cop named Tanimura who uncovers some major corruption happening in the police department, with the very top of the brass stinking.

In the game's amazing finale sequence, a total of four boss fights occur in quick succession, with Tanimura enjoying the best for last. Given the importance this character was given, it's a shame that he's never made an appearance in future Yakuza games. The argument that getting the actor's license for future games was expensive makes sense, but this is harder to swallow after seeing the protagonist of Judgment return for a future installment despite being a well-established actor himself.

9 Ares' Soul Is Never Mentioned Again

Mentioned In A Secret Message Of The First God Of War

God of War was a strong title on the PS2 that became a huge hit in no time. The Spartan may have calmed down in recent installments, but witnessing his angry persona as he hunts down Ares for the way he manipulated Kratos into killing his wife and child is quite satisfying. Players who went the extra mile to unlock the secret ending uncovered a unique piece of information.

This secret message reveals that Kratos has plans for Ares' soul, which he has kept in a hidden chamber. Players expecting something to crop up regarding this fact in later games were disappointed to see that this wasn't the case at all.

8 The Story Abruptly Ends Before Getting Into The Meat Of The Conflict

Budgetary Constraints Stopped Tyranny From Reaching Its Full Potential

Tyranny is easily one of the best-written modern CRPGs that players can have a great time with, making it all the more disappointing that the title never got the ending it deserved. Budgetary restrictions led to the title ending just before getting into the meat of the conflict, meaning that no one ever found out what Kyros, the overlord and the game's major antagonist, even looked like.

A lot of plotlines were either hastily wrapped up in the epilogue or barely addressed, which is pretty disappointing for obvious reasons. It's a tepid ending to a CRPG that is amazing to enjoy right until that point, and players can't help but wonder how much fun this game would be if it was given the means to achieve its fullest potential.

7 The Importance Of Eve

A Supposedly Important Bloodline Is Just Dropped With No Aplomb

Assassin's Creed: Brotherhood is a great game that builds up on the success of the second mainline entry in the series. It's a fun title to play through, with Ezio's character being as engaging as ever . However, one particular plot point in the game that's never really brought up later is a message Subject 16 gives to Desmond in the real world.

Related
The 18 Best Collector’s Editions You Need in Your Library

Games with statues, replicas, bookends. Only unique games get this treatment. Here are the top 15 collector's edition games you need in your library.

This appears in a hidden scene, with Desmond being asked to find Eve, the first woman, since her bloodline is apparently going to be really important to decide the fate of the world. With this in mind, fans were pretty aggrieved to find out that this arc was never picked up in later games, which makes the infamous real-world segments of Assassin's Creed even harder to sit through.

6 Harley Quinn's Tragic Pregnancy

A Dark And Twisted Plotline That Isn't Explored At All

Harley Quinn is one of the most popular villains of all time , with her partnership with the Joker being pretty engaging to witness in the Arkham series. However, in the second game, this romance is cut short when the Joker breathes his last, leaving her consumed by obsession and grief, but with hope.

In the game, players can find a hidden detail with a positive pregnancy test on Harley Quinn's table. However, instead of building on this, the arc was promptly discarded in the Harley Quinn's Revenge DLC, with Rocksteady backing out of this story and labeling the pregnancy test as a false positive.

5 Clearing Up Corruption In Riften

The Dragonborn Plays Little To No Role Here

The Elder Scrolls 5: Skyrim is one of the biggest video games of all time , with the world being absolutely loaded with content that will keep players invested for hundreds of hours, if not more. In fact, this game is so massive that a decent amount of content has been cut out of the title as well.

One of the characters in the game, Mjoll, is on a mission to remove corruption from the city of Riften. While this would've made for a great tale for the Dragonborn to explore, this expansive side quest was cut out of the game to save development time.

4 The Side Effects Of Red XIII's Experimentation

His Supposed Insanity After Being Experimented On By Hojo Is Just Abandoned

Final Fantasy 7 is a legendary JRPG with some really twisted happenings in the mix. One character who personifies the eerie side of this game brilliantly is Professor Hojo, a deranged maniac who experiments on live subjects and creates horrible monstrosities. Even his own body isn't off-limits.

Related
Troy Baker's 7 Most Iconic Video Game Roles (& 8 You Didn't Know About)

Troy Baker's acting career has been phenomenal, and while he's voiced many iconic characters, he's done just as many you might not know about.

At one point, Tifa asks Red XIII if he would be fine, given that anyone experimented on by Hojo slowly loses their sanity over time. This plotline is never brought up, leading to Red XIII being pretty underdeveloped when compared to some of the other party members in the game.

3 Ethan's Blackouts

A Supposed Psychic Link Between Him And The Origami Killer That's Conveniently Abandoned

Heavy Rain was a massive success for Quantic Dream, with players getting heavily invested in Ethan's quest to save his son from the Origami Killer . Early on in the game, Ethan experiences several blackouts, which ultimately leads to Shawn being kidnapped.

However, these blackouts are removed in the final half of the story and never really explained. One possible explanation was that these blackouts were being triggered because of a psychic connection between the Origami Killer and Ethan, but this idea was scrapped since it ruined the realism of the game.

2 Kiryu's Relationship With Kaoru

Their Romantic Relationship Is Conveniently Dropped At The Start Of Yakuza 3

Kiryu Kazuma is one of the greatest video game characters of all time, and the second game in the Yakuza series lets him interact with a potential love interest. This romance blossoms into something real, with Kiryu and Kaoru sharing an intimate kiss moments before their assumed demise, only for the bomb that was threatening their lives to never go off.

While they share a powerful moment, Kaoru ends up going away to fulfill her duties as an enforcer of the law. She never really does anything of note after that, which makes for a pretty disappointing conclusion to what could've been a great romance.

1 Dark Energy And Aging Stars

The Threat Of The Reapers Overshadows Any Other Cataclysmic Event

Mass Effect 2 is one of the greatest action RPGs ever made, with players getting the opportunity to expand their squad by helping out several possible recruits. One of these characters is fan-favorite Tali'Zorah nar Rayya, who is one of the most compelling characters in the series.

Tali mentions a star that is losing energy at a rapid pace because of dark energy, which is certainly quite sinister and was even meant to serve as a major source of motivation for the Reapers to take over the universe in the sequel . However, many key figures in BioWare departed, and the motivations of the Reapers were altered significantly in subsequent games.

More
The Most Historically Accurate Video Games Ever Made, Ranked

Many developers play fast and loose with factual accuracy in favor of creating an enjoyable playing experience. However, this has started to change.

item.title: Wuthering Waves: Flautist Locations
item.description:
The Flautist is an Elite Class Echo that can be found roaming the lands of Wuthering Waves . Defeating it will prove to be a bit of a challenge thanks to its higher HP and sturdy shield. Additionally, the Flautist is rarely seen alone, so make sure to be prepared to fight a group of enemies at all times.

The Flautist in WuWa is one of the many enemies that offer drops that are used to level up characters in Wuthering Waves . There are four drops in total; LF Whisperin Core, MF Whisperin Core, HF Whisperin Core, and FF Whisperin Core. The higher-tier materials are also obtained through synthesizing.

Related
Wuthering Waves: Havoc Rover Build Guide

Havoc Rover is a strong main DPS and the second version of the main character in Wuthering Waves.

Flautist Locations In Wuthering Waves

Flautist are found in specific areas and beating them will not only reward materials in Wuthering Waves , but Resonators will obtain the ability to transform into one and emit a laser that deals continuous Electro damage.

Withering Frontline

Immediately east of the Withering Frontline, there will be a Flautist. A bit northeast is another one that can be found along the path.

Stone Pile Plain

Fast travel to the Stone Pile Plain Resonance Beacon and head out of the cave to glide down south. A Flautist with a group of enemies in Wuthering Waves can be seen from the distance.

Nostalgia Isle and Sea of Flames

Head to Nostalgia Isle Resonance Beacon and run west to find the Flautist. While the previous locations only have one enemy, the Sea of Flames contains more Flautists.

From the Sea of Flames Resonance Beacon, go slightly southeast to find the TD. Return to the same Beacon but go northeast this time to defeat the enemy. Proceed northwest to find one in an open area and another inside a building.

The latter can be reached by climbing the building and jumping inside.

The Sea of Flames will constantly deplete players’ HP so it can become a hassle to collect the materials freely. To remove the debuff, complete the We Promise, We Deliver quest in Wuthering Waves .

Forbidden Forest

Go to the Forbidden Forest to encounter three Flautists surrounded by a group of small enemies.

Tiger’s Maw Mine

Fast-travel to the Resonance Beacon east of the Lampylumen Myriad boss in Wuthering Waves , turn around, then drop to the cliff below to find a Flautist with a Havoc Warrior.

To reach this hidden Resonance Beacon, players can go to the Waypoint north of Corroded Ruins, then go west to the river stream . Follow the stream inside a cave until players reach the hidden Resonance Beacon east of the Lampylumen Myriad boss in Wuthering Waves .

Fallen Grave

The first step should be to complete the Stygian Lacrimosa Exploration quest upon reaching Union Level 25 to get rid of the icy storm stopping players from progressing inside the area. Next, from the Fallen Grave’s southern Resonance Beacon, head northwest to find a Flautist and then go northeast to see three enemies.

item.title: God of War Needs to Redefine Kratos' Purpose Clearly and Quickly
item.description:
Highlights

  • God of War Ragnarok sets the stage for Atreus to take over as the protagonist, as Kratos embraces a more peaceful role in the story.
  • Kratos has evolved into a more introspective character, leaving room for Atreus to face his own challenges and grow independently.
  • The future of the God of War franchise may see Atreus stepping out of Kratos' shadow, taking on new adventures and narrative directions.

It's not clear when, but a new God of War game is coming. God of War Ragnarok , though not ending on a cliffhanger, doesn't offer enough closure to justify another franchise hiatus. In other words, God of War 's story must go on, as there are still questions that need to be answered.

There's a fair chance that Atreus will lead the next God of War , as Kratos ends Ragnarok , and especially its Valhalla DLC, with a much more pacifistic disposition. It's heavily suggested that he will fill the void left by Tyr's death, effectively becoming the Norse God of War, assuming the role of a leader rather than a maverick warrior. More importantly, Kratos's primary motivation for fighting has been removed, and while it wouldn't be unreasonable for the next game to introduce a new antagonist that forces Kratos out of "retirement," all signs point to the titular god taking a back seat moving forward, letting Atreus carve out the future of the series.

Related
God of War Ragnarok’s Muspelheim Trials and Valhalla DLC May Be Two Pieces of The Same Puzzle

Offering similar gameplay challenge types, GoW: Ragnarok's Valhalla DLC and Muspelheim trials could be further elevated by combining the two.

The Next God of War Game Should Be Clear About Kratos's Role

Kratos: To Retire or Not to Retire

Kratos undergoes a dramatic transformation in God of War Ragnarok , a metamorphosis that was sparked in God of War 2018. Wracked with guilt, shame, and fear for the fate of his son, Kratos spends much of his time in these games running from his past. By the time Valhalla ends, though, he has incorporated his darker side and come to terms with his shadowy history, ultimately becoming a more multifaceted, thoughtful person in the process.

This is great storytelling, but it leaves a lot up to interpretation as far as future narrative potential is concerned. It seems clear that God of War 's 'sad dad' arc has come to an end, and with that storytelling font exhausted, there's not as much room for Kratos to be a protagonist once more. The antagonistic forces of the Norse realms have all been defeated as well, so it's hard to imagine how much more potential there is without another major shift in setting. Despite this, Ragnarok and the Valhalla DLC aren't exactly conclusive when it comes to Kratos' future. Right now, he's straddling the line between his classic action-hero persona and a more wizened leader, prioritizing wisdom and collaboration over combat.

Many have speculated that God of War will visit Egypt next , so perhaps this would provide new narrative routes for Kratos. However, it's more likely that Atreus would be the one to tackle foreign lands, as he is on a pilgrimage and Kratos has no obvious reason to leave the Norse realms.

Kratos' Role Informs Atreus'

Assuming Atreus does indeed pivot to the position of primary protagonist in the next God of War , he will be fighting an uphill battle to get out of Kratos' shadow. For this to happen, Atreus needs to be further developed: his solo game needs to pit him against significant challenges and force him into tough decisions that will help shape his identity as an independent hero. Atreus has dealt with challenges before, but he's always had his father for support, both literally and from a metanarrative standpoint. If Atreus is going to be the main protagonist , the focus of the story needs to be on him, not Kratos.

This will be challenging if Kratos embarks on another high-stakes adventure in the next game. History has shown how challenging it can be to nail the dual-protagonist story structure in a game, and there's an extra layer of complication introduced when one of the protagonists is a long-time, iconic hero, and the other has only been introduced a few years ago. Atreus could share the spotlight with Kratos in the next game or he could be the star, but not both. Being clear about Kratos' role in the overarching God of War narrative is crucial to defining this narrative focus.
